Choices:  A: make noise B: have tea C: make time D: make payments E: take time<n><n>### Response:		It depends on the kind of bank you're looking at. Big banks have become more aggressive in recent years and are now offering "bigger" services, but at the cost of putting customers first. The average person should be looking for what's better for your banking needs, not what's better for the bank's bottom line.<n>### Rationale:A bank is a place where you can keep your money for safekeeping and deposit. You might also make payments or withdrawals at a bank. Banks may be private or public. A public bank can be as small <n>as just one employee—you—and just as large as the most impressive multi-billion-dollar corporate bank. Banks can also be "private." A private bank is a building that is set aside for people to do their banking business. Private banks don't <n>do much banking work. They might have one or two tellers at the time when you're at the counter, but they're usually pretty busy and keep you waiting. In a private bank, tellers give out bank checks, which you can then cash anywhere else. In most <n>private banks, the teller is paid a salary or <n>commission by the bank and is therefore expected to make deposits and withdrawals as quickly as possible so that it doesn't cost more than it's worth to do things like cash checks or do other services. Private banks are usually run by <n>a board of directors. <n><n>### Input<n><n>A. Find the odd one out. The questions are: B. You don't notice because the dog C. You don't care D. You won't want to. Rationale: A. When I say the dog, I don't mean the dog. I just mean that there's a dog in my home. So, the dog would be odd because it's not what you'd normally expect in a house. B. The word "car" is used more often than any other word in these questions, but "car" is not an item. We would use the word "car" in a sentence where it refers to a vehicle, like "Why is the car a car when I'm buying it?" But in this case, <n>"car" actually means something else. So, "Find the odd one out" indicates

Choices:  A: eat cake B: buy C: interests D: complex E: learn about<n><n>### Response:		<n>Rationales:<n>Option A: eat cake has no real meaning; we don't know what this woman was looking at or what her intention is. <n> Option B: "buy" is an option, but one should be suspicious if the task is referring to "something", and yet it turns out to be asking about cake.<n> Option D: Complex and learn are not appropriate choices because if she is examining the "thing", then presumably she is taking a closer look at it, not performing a complex analysis.<n> Therefore, we can reject D: complex. <n> The question is asking about what she is "considering" with it. <n> Option C: "buy" also suggests a transactional activity, with the woman buying the thing. If so, it is unlikely that she would not only examine the thing, then consider buying it.<n> Therefore, we must reject C: buy, as well. <n> If the task is asking about what she was examining, and considering a further action on it, then options E: learn is the answer.<n><n>Answer: E: learn<n><n>### Input :What is the purpose of a vineyard? Choices: <n> A) It can be used to play sports with. B) Produce food. C) Can be used to entertain guests with. D) Can be used as a resting place. E) Can be used to play instruments.<n><n>###Response: A) It can be played sports (vine) and produce food. (farm). So, it is the best choice because the vineyard can produce food and provide fun for sports.<n><n>Answer: (C) Can be used to relax.<n><n>###Input: If the people are all dead, what can the person in the hospital do with the other items, which includes a pillow? Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question is asking for a type of plumbing that would not help quench thirst. <n>2. This means we are looking for a source of plumbing that does not provide drinkable water. <n>3. We know that plumbing in our own home (D) and water fountains (E) both usually provide drinkable water. <n>4. A wall (B) could have plumbing inside it for water flow, but again this water would typically be drinkable. <n>5. A show (C) is vague, but if it's referring to a place like a concert or theater, they typically have drinkable water available.<n>6. An oil refinery (A), however, has plumbing which is used for the processing and refining of oil, not water. <n>7. Therefore, the type of plumbing in an oil refinery would not be of use to you if you are thirsty. So, the answer is A: oil refineries.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Rationales: 1. The question asked what a person isn't doing yet when they are beginning work. This involves identifying activities that are not immediate consequences of beginning work.<n>2. It is difficult to make assumptions about a person's physical state, so options B: resting and C: tiredness aren't appropriate because they don't necessarily correlate with starting work. <n>3. "Working" is not the correct answer, because if a person is beginning work, they are technically already in the process of working.<n>4. Option E: momentum is not applicable as it's not a verb or something you could do as per the theme of the question. <n>5. Therefore, option D: accomplishing is the most logical answer. This is because accomplishing suggests the person has already reached some level of success or completion in their work, which would not be possible if they are only just beginning. So, when a person is beginning work, they can't be accomplishing yet.<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:If a human wants to enjoy another human's company, where might they go? So, when a person is beginning work, they can't be accomplishing yet.<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:What is it called when you slowly cook using a grill? Choices:  A: backyard B: restaurant C: crockpot D: neighbor's house E: barbeque<n><n>### Response:		If you slowly cook something using a grill, it would be called barbecue cooking.  Barbeque and barbecue are both common spellings for barbecue as described by [Chambers](https://www.chambers-dictonary.com/english/-b-1/barbecue) as "a barbecue." Barbecue is defined as "a meal cooked on a barbecue grill." This is not applicable to the instruction because the context is "slowly cooking," so the definition of barbecue needs to be restricted to barbecue grills. According to [Chambers](http://www.chambs.co.nz/def2500/def-5792.html), grill, grilling, and griller all imply "to cook food, typically meat, on a grill/grilling surface." While [Cambridge University Press](https://dictionary.cambridge.org/dictionary/english/grill) states that grill "a long, metal surface for cooking meat over fire or under a hot electric light," I think we can assume that if someone is using a grill to cook something slowly, they are using a grill as defined by Chambers. Finally, according to [Cambridge University](https://dictionary.reference.com/help/common/dictionary/dictionary.help/topic/grilling) a slow barbecue (also grilling) is a cooking technique that "involves using indirect heat and long exposure to high temperature, usually for smoky flavor." This is the most appropriate definition of the word "slowly" in the instruction. <n>

It is the responsibility of the user to handle those errors.<n>    - If adding the input to the output results in it changing the OUTPUT the RESPONSE needs to handle that by reassigning an output<n>

It is difficult to make assumptions about a person's physical state, so options B: resting and C: tiredness aren't appropriate because they don't necessarily correlate with starting work. <n>3. "Working" is not the correct answer, because if a person is beginning work, they are technically already in the process of working.<n>4. Option E: momentum is not applicable as it's not a verb or something you could do as per the theme of the question. <n>5. Therefore, option D: accomplishing is the most logical answer. This is because accomplishing suggests the person has already reached some level of success or completion in their work, which would not be possible if they are only just beginning. So, when a person is beginning work, they can't be accomplishing yet.<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:Sean was lying about the body, but he was very scared.  He constantly worried about what? Choices:  A: the reward money B: hurt feelings C: being found out D: problems E: trouble<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question is asking for a type of plumbing that would not help quench thirst. <n>2. An oil refinery (A), however, has plumbing which is used for the processing and refining of oil, not water. <n>7. Option E: momentum is not applicable as it's not a verb or something you could do as per the theme of the question. <n>5. Therefore, option D: accomplishing is the most logical answer. Choices:  A: music store B: dance hall C: orchestra D: symphony E: tennessee<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Explanation:<n>In this question, the fiddle is likely to be playing somewhere that is playing other music.<n>Option C: orchestra is incorrect because an orchestra could include numerous instruments in addition to fiddles.<n>Option B: dance hall is incorrect because while a dance hall could feature fiddles, it is more likely that they will be playing a different type of music.<n>Option E: tennessee is incorrect because this state is not known for its fiddle music, but rather other types of music.<n>Option D: symphony is correct because a symphony is a type of musical ensemble that typically includes a variety of instruments, including fiddles, that can be played in unison. <n>Option A: music store is the best choice because it is the only option that allows for the fiddle to be playing, as opposed to the fiddle to be located for sale.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question is asking for a type of plumbing that would not help quench thirst. <n>2. This means we are looking for a source of plumbing that does not provide drinkable water. <n>3. We know that plumbing in our own home (D) and water fountains (E) both usually provide drinkable water. <n>4. A wall (B) could have plumbing inside it for water flow, but again this water would typically be drinkable. <n>5. A show (C) is vague, but if it's referring to a place like a concert or theater, they typically have drinkable water available.<n>6. An oil refinery (A), however, has plumbing which is used for the processing and refining of oil, not water. <n>7. Therefore, the type of plumbing in an oil refinery would not be of use to you if you are thirsty. So, the answer is A: oil refineries.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Rationales: 1. The question asked what a person isn't doing yet when they are beginning work. This involves identifying activities that are not immediate consequences of beginning work.<n>2. It is difficult to make assumptions about a person's physical state, so options B: resting and C: tiredness aren't appropriate because they don't necessarily correlate with starting work. <n>3. "Working" is not the correct answer, because if a person is beginning work, they are technically already in the process of working.<n>4. Option E: momentum is not applicable as it's not a verb or something you could do as per the theme of the question. <n>5. Therefore, option D: accomplishing is the most logical answer. This is because accomplishing suggests the person has already reached some level of success or completion in their work, which would not be possible if they are only just beginning. So, when a person is beginning work, they can't be accomplishing yet.<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:What do drugs do? Choices:  A: damage B: cloud mind C: lower i.q D: cause illness E: cause accidents<n><n>### Response:		Drugs affect memory and motor skills to a severe degree. Drugs damage the user by slowing down their brain as they are being consumed and lowering IQ, but not so dramatically that a user becomes ill in that moment. However, it has been proven that excessive drug use can cause many diseases such as dementia and schizophrenia. These diseases take time to manifest, so while a user is not ill in the moment, the effects can be felt after the fact. Furthermore, drugs can cause accidents due to the effects they have on the user's motor skills.<n><n>### Input<n><n>### Demostration

Choices:  A: backery B: ham sandwich C: fridge D: butcher shop E: freezer<n><n>### Response:		A is not the answer.<n><n>### Rationale:<n><n>You chose the answer that sounded aesthetically correct (like when you say a "ham sandwicth" in American English) instead of actually answering the question.<n>The question is asking where you can store meat that will last a long time.<n>If you store the meat in a backery, then they can have meat as long as the backery is open.<n>When they close the backery, the meat would most likely go rotten soon.<n>If you store it at a butcher shop, the meat would last as long as the butcher shop remains opened.<n><n>If you store it in the fridge, then the meat will last as long as the fridge is open.<n><n>If you stored it in the freezer, it would last as long as you kept electricity on in the house, the freezer stays closed, the freezer contains no other frozen foods, there is not a hole in the freezer, and the freezer isn't exposed to high temperature or fire (e.g. a gas stove burns out and the air from the stove is sucked into the freezer causing it to malfunction).<n>But that's not what the question asked. The question asked where you can store meat for a long time, and if you store it in the freezer you are already storing it a long time, in perpetuity.<n>You could not really have chosen better than a butcher shop for that exact reason, though - the meat would not last a long time in the butcher shop in the sense of "will it still be there later in time," but in the sense of "could the meat go bad" and you are already excluding the chance of the meat going bad.<n><n>So, if you store the meat in the fridge, it will last a long time as long as you keep your fridge open. If you store it in the cold, it will last longer in the cold.<n><n>If we're going to talk about it as long as the frige is open, then it's going to have to be the frige because of the butcher shop, unless the question is "where can you store meat to last indefinite time" and in that case the butcher shop could be the answer.<n>If you store meat in a freezer for an indefinite amount of

Choices:  A: empathy B: anxiety C: knowlege D: falling down E: hear things<n><n>### Response:		<n>A: B: C: D: E:<n><n>```<n>[45,2]<n>{<n> "contentType":"/query",<n> "question":false,<n> "question2":false,<n> "headline":"{Ans}",<n> "answers":[<n>    {<n>     "answerIndex":45,<n>     "correct":true,<n>     "answerType":"answer",<n>     "choices":[ <n>      {<n>       "answer":"oil refineries",<n>       "correct":false<n>      },<n>      {<n>       ""<n>      }.<n>     ],<n>     "text":"oil refineres"<n>    }.<n> ],<n> "isCorrect":true,<n> "timeStamp":"1651752475363"<n>}<n>[35,2]<n>{}<n>```<n><n>### Input :<n>Where could you find a good place to stay in a large city? Choices: C: a place to rent<n>D: a good hotel E: a place to drink<n><n>### Output:<n>```<n>[C,D,E]<n>{<n> "answerIndex":C,<n> "answerType":"ans",<n> "isMultiAnswer":false,<n> "answer":"Where could you find a place to stay, like a good hotel?",<n> "choices":[<n>   {<n>    "index":C,<n>    "correct":false,<n>     "answer":"What if you had an answer to this question, where could you stay?",<n>   }.<n>  ]<n>}<n>{<n> "answerType":"question",<n> "choices":"Which of the following are the best?",<n> "isCorrect";false,<n> "text":"Whats the best thing about finding a place to visit or where to stay?",<n> "timeStamp":1651768048850,<n> "ansIndex":["a place to rent", "a good hotel", "a place to drink"]<n>}<n>{<n>    "isCorrect":false<n>}<n>```<n><n>## Input : A: oil refineres, B: Wall, C: Showd, D: own homes.<n><n>## Output : Wall<n><n>## Input : the students did have homework but they just couldn't get it done.<n><n>## Output: 
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question is asking for a type of plumbing that would not help quench thirst. <n>2. This means we are looking for a source of plumbing that does not provide drinkable water. <n>3. We know that plumbing in our own home (D) and water fountains (E) both usually provide drinkable water. <n>4. A wall (B) could have plumbing inside it for water flow, but again this water would typically be drinkable. <n>5. A show (C) is vague, but if it's referring to a place like a concert or theater, they typically have drinkable water available.<n>6. An oil refinery (A), however, has plumbing which is used for the processing and refining of oil, not water. <n>7. Therefore, the type of plumbing in an oil refinery would not be of use to you if you are thirsty. So, the answer is A: oil refineries.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Rationales: 1. The question asked what a person isn't doing yet when they are beginning work. This involves identifying activities that are not immediate consequences of beginning work.<n>2. It is difficult to make assumptions about a person's physical state, so options B: resting and C: tiredness aren't appropriate because they don't necessarily correlate with starting work. <n>3. "Working" is not the correct answer, because if a person is beginning work, they are technically already in the process of working.<n>4. Option E: momentum is not applicable as it's not a verb or something you could do as per the theme of the question. <n>5. Therefore, option D: accomplishing is the most logical answer. This is because accomplishing suggests the person has already reached some level of success or completion in their work, which would not be possible if they are only just beginning. So, when a person is beginning work, they can't be accomplishing yet.<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:What is a good result of losing weight? Choices:  A: increased energy B: healthier C: loose skin D: beauty E: death<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Answer A: Incorrect. Losing weight can come with a number of positive outcomes, but it cannot result in more energy.<n><n>Answer B: Incorrect. Having a healthier body can obviously be a major positive outcome when weight is lost, however, it does not follow that the result is the person has more energy.<n><n><n><n>#### Incorrect answers<n><n>* Incorrect because answer has a typo- 'lose'.<n>* Incorrect because this word should be 'lose'.<n><n>### Input<n>What is a way to get more energy if your diet is high in carbohydrates?<n><n>### Response<n><n>Answer A: Avoiding carbs completely.<n><n>Answer B. The answer is correct,  Answer C: is incorrect because there are several way to get energy, and there is not really any way to eat a diet with more protein than carbohydrats.<n><n>### Incorrect answers<n>* Incorrect because "avoid them all together".<n>* Incorrect because option 2 is not appropriate.<n>* Incorrect because the two words are spaced incorrectly.<n><n>### Input <n><n>Which of the options mentioned at the top for a good result of losing is a benefit of dieting, but not a good result?<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>Answer E: Healthier appearance of the skin. If someone has loose skin, they can still lose weight and look different, by tightening up their skin.<n><n><n><n><n>### The most important part is writing<n><n>### The following shows how to respond to an instruction <n>#Instruction 1<n>Write a response that appropriately answers the following questions. <n>The following questions have multiple correct options, and different methods of response. <n><n>### Your response can choose between 2 methods of response<n><n>#### 1. A response can follow the format below, and the following structure:<n>### Instruction 2<n><n>#### Instruction 3:<n><n>### Method 2<n><n>#### Method 1:<n><n>### Responses are written using the following: The first sentence should write the topic, using the same word as in the task. After the topic, a response should include the appropriate answer for the question, in full sentences. Each sentence includes 1 action.

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question is asking for a type of plumbing that would not help quench thirst. <n>2. This means we are looking for a source of plumbing that does not provide drinkable water. <n>3. We know that plumbing in our own home (D) and water fountains (E) both usually provide drinkable water. <n>4. A wall (B) could have plumbing inside it for water flow, but again this water would typically be drinkable. <n>5. A show (C) is vague, but if it's referring to a place like a concert or theater, they typically have drinkable water available.<n>6. An oil refinery (A), however, has plumbing which is used for the processing and refining of oil, not water. <n>7. Therefore, the type of plumbing in an oil refinery would not be of use to you if you are thirsty. So, the answer is A: oil refineries.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Rationales: 1. The question asked what a person isn't doing yet when they are beginning work. This involves identifying activities that are not immediate consequences of beginning work.<n>2. It is difficult to make assumptions about a person's physical state, so options B: resting and C: tiredness aren't appropriate because they don't necessarily correlate with starting work. <n>3. "Working" is not the correct answer, because if a person is beginning work, they are technically already in the process of working.<n>4. Option E: momentum is not applicable as it's not a verb or something you could do as per the theme of the question. <n>5. Therefore, option D: accomplishing is the most logical answer. This is because accomplishing suggests the person has already reached some level of success or completion in their work, which would not be possible if they are only just beginning. So, when a person is beginning work, they can't be accomplishing yet.<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:The accountant used a calculator regularly, he kept one at home and one at the what? Choices:  A: desk drawer B: desktop C: office D: wristwatch E: city hall<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Input:The accountant useda calculator regularly, hekept one at home and oneat the what? <n><n>### Rationales: <n><n>The question asks for the location of the accountant's calculator(s). <n><n>Option A) "home" is incorrect because it does not explain how the calculator is typically used. <n><n>Option B) "desk drawer" is incorrect because it is the location at which the calculator is kept, but not necessarily where it is used. <n><n>The remaining options could all be locations where a calculator is used. <n> <n>Option C) "office" is incorrect because it specifically refers to the location at the accountant keeps his calculator, although it does not distinguish between the home and work offices. <n><n>Option D) "wristwatch" is incorrect because it makes no sense as a location for a calculator. <n>    <n>Option E) "city hall" is incorrect due to the redundancy in the words "desk drawer".  <n>    <n>Answer: C: office<n><n>-----------------------<n><n>Below is an instruction that describes how to complete a task. So, if a person is very  depressed they can't be murdered.<n><n>## Option E:  cyanide<n><n>This is not an option which is correct according to the language of the question. A "rhetorical question" is a question asked for the sake of discourse rather than to receive an answer.<n>The speaker is telling the listener that all the listed options are too specific to consider the general population who are likely to have a caring heart.<n>### Input:If "evolve" means "adapt", what is the antonym of "evolve?"<n><n>Choice: B: devolve <n>Response:  C: devolve<n><n>### Exemlpe:<n>```<n>The teacher told students to answer all the questions. When students had some questions,they asked the teacher. The teacher asked which questions to answer. The teacher also asked students what it was all about. Students didn't know what it was all about so they didn't know which question they were going to answer. There was nothing so the the students couldn't answer the question.<n>```<n><n>

Therefore, the type of plumbing in an oil refinery would not be of use to you if you are thirsty. So, the answer is A: oil refineries.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Rationales: 1. The question asked what a person isn't doing yet when they are beginning work. This involves identifying activities that are not immediate consequences of beginning work.<n>2. It is difficult to make assumptions about a person's physical state, so options B: resting and C: tiredness aren't appropriate because they don't necessarily correlate with starting work. <n>3. "Working" is not the correct answer, because if a person is beginning work, they are technically already in the process of working.<n>4. Option E: momentum is not applicable as it's not a verb or something you could do as per the theme of the question. <n>5. Therefore, option D: accomplishing is the most logical answer. This is because accomplishing suggests the person has already reached some level of success or completion in their work, which would not be possible if they are only just beginning. So, when a person is beginning work, they can't be accomplishing yet.<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:There weren't potatoes but actually a snake in his what? Choices:  A: burlap sack B: hot country C: purse D: pet shops E: deep grass<n><n>### Response:		<n>When the man found a snake in a burlap sack, he said, "There weren't _______."<n><n>### Rationale:<n>The correct answer is B: hot country<n><n>In the story, the man was traveling through a hot country, which could cause snakes to feel threatened and slumber in a burlap sacks. Because there were no potatoes, we can infer that the man is traveling through a hot climate that might not have an abundance of potatoes for sale.<n><n>### Option A: Burlap Sack<n>The man does not travel to places where he can buy a burlap sack or travels a long distance to buy a burlap sacks, but it is most likely that the man would buy a burlap sak to have if he finds a snake. Therefore, it is most likely that he bought the burlap sack before he came upon the snake.<n><n>### Rephrase:<n>When the traveller found a snake in his burlap sack, I believe that he would like to say that he did not travel to a place that he could buy a burlap sark. He would rather travel to a place that is more fertile and can grow a burlap sack abundant with potatoes.<n><n>### Explicit:<n>The traveller found a sak that had a snake in it. He believed that he did not travel through a place that allows people to grow a burlap sak.<n><n>When choosing your answer, write the appropriate letter in the blank in the question, for example: If the answer were A: Burlap Sacks, then you would write "A" in the blank. If the answer were B: Hot Country, then you would write 'B' in the blank.<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question is asking for a type of plumbing that would not help quench thirst. <n>2. This means we are looking for a source of plumbing that does not provide drinkable water. <n>3. We know that plumbing in our own home (D) and water fountains (E) both usually provide drinkable water. <n>4. A wall (B) could have plumbing inside it for water flow, but again this water would typically be drinkable. <n>5. A show (C) is vague, but if it's referring to a place like a concert or theater, they typically have drinkable water available.<n>6. An oil refinery (A), however, has plumbing which is used for the processing and refining of oil, not water. <n>7. Therefore, the type of plumbing in an oil refinery would not be of use to you if you are thirsty. So, the answer is A: oil refineries.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Rationales: 1. The question asked what a person isn't doing yet when they are beginning work. This involves identifying activities that are not immediate consequences of beginning work.<n>2. It is difficult to make assumptions about a person's physical state, so options B: resting and C: tiredness aren't appropriate because they don't necessarily correlate with starting work. <n>3. "Working" is not the correct answer, because if a person is beginning work, they are technically already in the process of working.<n>4. Option E: momentum is not applicable as it's not a verb or something you could do as per the theme of the question. <n>5. Therefore, option D: accomplishing is the most logical answer. This is because accomplishing suggests the person has already reached some level of success or completion in their work, which would not be possible if they are only just beginning. So, when a person is beginning work, they can't be accomplishing yet.<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:The new play was the go to performance of the year, all the crowds would stand and what? A show (C) is vague, but if it's referring to a place like a concert or theater, they typically have drinkable water available.<n>6. An oil refinery (A), however, has plumbing which is used for the processing and refining of oil, not water. <n>7. Choices:  A: illiterate B: knowledgable C: own house D: have enough food E: meet expectations<n><n>### Response:		<n><n><n>### Input:(A: illiterate) What is a person who is not well educated?<n><n>### Demolition:<n><n>The answer to this question would be opposite of the meaning given to A, (i.e. that A means a well educated person). Therefore we need to find another word that means illiterate.<n><n>(B: knowledgable) implies knowledge of something. Therefore we need to find a word that implies lack of knowledge.<n><n>### Input :(C: own house) What is a person without a house?<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>Since the answer to part (A and B) are the opposites of the words there, the answer to this would be the opposite of that of part (A and B). This also means that it would start with the same alphabet as the given answer.<n><n>### Answer:<n>```python<n>def solve():<n>    print('The people that are illiterate would have less house and less ability to meet expectaions.')<n><n>```

"Working" is not the correct answer, because if a person is beginning work, they are technically already in the process of working.<n>4. Option E: momentum is not applicable as it's not a verb or something you could do as per the theme of the question. <n>5. Therefore, option D: accomplishing is the most logical answer. Choices:  A: mail box B: suitcase C: front door D: bowl E: post office<n><n>### Response:		The question asks about a person delivering a letter directly to someone's hand in response to a request. Although option A: mail box does seem reasonable because letters are delivered through mailboxes, the question explicitly says a person delivers letters. A mailbox does not necessarily denote a human is handing someone a letter, and sometimes it is automated. As such, option A is incorrect.  Option B: suitcase may seem like the right answer because it can hold a letter, but again we cannot say definitively that a person is carrying the letter, just in case it is an automated delivery or not. This leaves us with three viable solutions. In option D: bowl, a person is definitely serving a letter to someone by handing it directly to them. Option E: post office does not necessarily mean a person delivers a letter to someone's hand, but it does show the person is serving the letter.  Option C: front door is most likely incorrect because we can't be sure it involves human interaction. So, option D: bowl and E: post office are both correct. <n><n>### Input : If someone is doing this, they are doing it in a way that will not be useful. Choices: 	A: making a mistake B: forgetting something C: cheating D: eating E: failing<n>Rationales: Option A: making a mistake 1. All five options have different meanings that indicate a way people are doing things. 2. So, it is confusing as the options are contradictory, as the question implies that if someone is doing something, they should do it successfully i.e. not make a mistake. So, we should not do A: making a mistake. 3. Option B: forgetting something isn't useful because by definition it means the person has forgotten something. 4. The next option D: eating doesn't quite make sense because eating sounds like something a person would actively be doing to achieve a goal. 5. Option E: failing isn't useful because that's an outcome of a behavior, not the behavior itself. 6. Therefore, it is clear that option C: cheating is the only viable option in this case. The question asks about doing something, but cheating is something being done, instead of simply being a method of executing something.<n><n>### Input - What is the opposite of something that moves forward

Choices:  A: music room B: music store C: music class D: medium E: house<n><n>### Response:		<n>1. If we are looking for a place to learn some music, the music room (A) is an easy assumption, and could be the case for some music. <n>2. A music store (B) may have music teachers, or could provide equipment for rent, which wouldn't really help us if we're looking to learn music. <n>3. The music class (D) could be a valid answer, unless it's referring to an "upright piano" class that would help with actually playing the instrument. <n>4. The medium (E) is a strange answer to get here, so we're left with two remaining answers, and A being the first choice, we're left with C: music class. Since we asked, "Where would someone learn to..." and the answer is referring to "learning to play an uprights piano," we know it has to be a person teaching another person to play the upright piano.<n><n>### Sample Instruction:<n>You've been given some new, blank sheets of paper. Where could you find the ink? Choices: A: music store B: library C: office supplies store D: pencil sharpener E: home<n><n>### Sample Response:<n>1. It isn't necessary to buy blank paper in order to put ink on paper, so B: library would not have ink available to you. <n>2. The office supply store (D) may have ink pens or other ink-related items like markers, but the correct answer would still be "home" because we assumed we would be provided with the ink in order to "start writing." <n>3. Similarly, it's likely you do not have a pencil sharpener (E) in your home, and your home (A) wouldn't naturally have pencil sharpeners. <n>4. Therefore, the correct answer would be C: office supplies store.<n><n>### Required Task:<n><n>You've given a set of paper and a pencil. Where could you go to find the paint?<n>You are required to provide a minimum six word response.<n>

Choices: <n>A: a baker B: a pastry chef C: a cook D: a butcher E: a cashier<n><n>### Response :<n><n>D <n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question is asking for a type of plumbing that would not help quench thirst. <n>2. This means we are looking for a source of plumbing that does not provide drinkable water. <n>3. We know that plumbing in our own home (D) and water fountains (E) both usually provide drinkable water. <n>4. A wall (B) could have plumbing inside it for water flow, but again this water would typically be drinkable. <n>5. A show (C) is vague, but if it's referring to a place like a concert or theater, they typically have drinkable water available.<n>6. An oil refinery (A), however, has plumbing which is used for the processing and refining of oil, not water. <n>7. Therefore, the type of plumbing in an oil refinery would not be of use to you if you are thirsty. So, the answer is A: oil refineries.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Rationales: 1. The question asked what a person isn't doing yet when they are beginning work. This involves identifying activities that are not immediate consequences of beginning work.<n>2. It is difficult to make assumptions about a person's physical state, so options B: resting and C: tiredness aren't appropriate because they don't necessarily correlate with starting work. <n>3. "Working" is not the correct answer, because if a person is beginning work, they are technically already in the process of working.<n>4. Option E: momentum is not applicable as it's not a verb or something you could do as per the theme of the question. <n>5. Therefore, option D: accomplishing is the most logical answer. This is because accomplishing suggests the person has already reached some level of success or completion in their work, which would not be possible if they are only just beginning. So, when a person is beginning work, they can't be accomplishing yet.<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:Where would you be able to hear a bassoon played in an unpleasing fashion? Choices:  A: orchestra B: baritone woodwind sound C: symphony D: play music E: high school band<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Input:"Another popular way to travel in Canada is the Amtrak. What two different train types does Amtrak operate?"<n><n>## Response:<n>

"Working" is not the correct answer, because if a person is beginning work, they are technically already in the process of working.<n>4. A wall (B) could have plumbing inside it for water flow, but again this water would typically be drinkable. <n>5. An oil refinery (A), however, has plumbing which is used for the processing and refining of oil, not water. <n>7. Therefore, the type of plumbing in an oil refinery would not be of use to you if you are thirsty. This involves identifying activities that are not immediate consequences of beginning work.<n>2. It is difficult to make assumptions about a person's physical state, so options B: resting and C: tiredness aren't appropriate because they don't necessarily correlate with starting work. <n>3. "Working" is not the correct answer, because if a person is beginning work, they are technically already in the process of working.<n>4. Option E: momentum is not applicable as it's not a verb or something you could do as per the theme of the question. <n>5. Therefore, option D: accomplishing is the most logical answer. This is because accomplishing suggests the person has already reached some level of success or completion in their work, which would not be possible if they are only just beginning. So, when a person is beginning work, they can't be accomplishing yet.<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:What could you add a line to? "Working" is not the correct answer, because if a person is beginning work, they are technically already in the process of working.<n>4. Option E: momentum is not applicable as it's not a verb or something you could do as per the theme of the question. <n>5. Therefore, option D: accomplishing is the most logical answer. Choices:  A: shake hands B: control events C: talk to each other D: think creatively E: dress themselves<n><n>### Response:		<n>A: Shake hands<n><n>### Justify:<n>The people in class were most likely instructed to brainstrom ideas since this is a group activity and the only appropriate response is for them to work together. Brainstorming requires the people in class to use their minds, so it makes sense for this to be their most important activity. We know this because the people in class need to use their minds to brainstorm together and work as a class team to arrive at new ideas. This makes the most sense because the people in class can't control events or think creatively, but instead can use their minds to think critically and contribute to the brainstorming session.<n><n>### Input"While reading, what is the sound of ink making its way from a quill to a parchment?" Choices:  A"swooshing" B"whizzing" C"scratching" D"writing" E"chomping"<n><n>### Justifiy:<n>A: Swoshing<n><n>### Justification:<n>A sound is defined as a sensation that occurs when something physical comes in contact with a surface. This would most likely be a sensation experienced while reading. It could also be experienced while working with papers or books, such as when flipping through the pages or tearing them apart. <n><n>### The sound of ink making it's way from a quill and parchment is defined as:<n><n>- The quill is a feathered pen, used for writing before metal nibs became available. The quill is sharpened to a point at the tip and then covered with ink and dipped into a container. <n>- Parchment is a type of paper with a smooth, even surface made from animal skin coated with animal guts and lime. <n><n>A sensation experienced while inking a parchment with a quill would be described as a "swoshing" sound, because the ink is being pushed out of the container by the quill, spreading the ink across the surface of the parchment. This would be contrasted to a "scratching" sound, which is not applicable as it would describe the quill making contact with the surface, rather than the ink moving through it. <n><n>##

Choices:  A: boat B: ocean C: pond D: end of line E: ocean<n><n>### Response:		The question is asking for some type of fish that might be found in your backyard. This means we need to look for a type of fish that lives near the ground.<n><n>### The type of fish we are looking for does not need water to live. Therefore, an ocean or pond is not appropriate.<n><n>### A boat is too large and would only have fish in it if a person was going out on the ocean. Since we are looking for a type of fish near the ground, this is not relevant.<n><n>### Option B: ocean could be mistaken for option A: boat, so it is appropriate to exclude that one choice.<n><n>### Based on logic and the context of the question it is clear that the answer is E: ocean.<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question is asking for a type of plumbing that would not help quench thirst. <n>2. This means we are looking for a source of plumbing that does not provide drinkable water. <n>3. We know that plumbing in our own home (D) and water fountains (E) both usually provide drinkable water. <n>4. A wall (B) could have plumbing inside it for water flow, but again this water would typically be drinkable. <n>5. A show (C) is vague, but if it's referring to a place like a concert or theater, they typically have drinkable water available.<n>6. An oil refinery (A), however, has plumbing which is used for the processing and refining of oil, not water. <n>7. Therefore, the type of plumbing in an oil refinery would not be of use to you if you are thirsty. So, the answer is A: oil refineries.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Rationales: 1. The question asked what a person isn't doing yet when they are beginning work. This involves identifying activities that are not immediate consequences of beginning work.<n>2. It is difficult to make assumptions about a person's physical state, so options B: resting and C: tiredness aren't appropriate because they don't necessarily correlate with starting work. <n>3. "Working" is not the correct answer, because if a person is beginning work, they are technically already in the process of working.<n>4. Option E: momentum is not applicable as it's not a verb or something you could do as per the theme of the question. <n>5. Therefore, option D: accomplishing is the most logical answer. This is because accomplishing suggests the person has already reached some level of success or completion in their work, which would not be possible if they are only just beginning. So, when a person is beginning work, they can't be accomplishing yet.<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:What are you hoping to achieve when talking to someone? Choices:  A: communicating with others B: hurt feelings C: dry mouth D: intimacy E: changing behavior<n><n>### Response:		When talking to someone, you would be hoping to achieve communication with others. You may hope to achieve other things, but communication between two people is the main hope you'd have for talking, since it refers to talking with others. You may, for example, think you hope to change someone's behavior, but in reality you'd want to communicate with them. This is because you'd be doing or saying things to have an influence on them (change their behavior), and if that works out then you'd consider that to have gone well in communication with others. You can't be hoping to achieve hurt feelings or dry mouth, because those are not things that are inherent in conversation.<n><n>### Input:"If you've never made a mistake, you've never made anything."  Choices: A: John Dryden B: Albert Einstein C: Albert Einstein D: E.F. Hutton E: Samuel F. Smith<n><n>### Response:"If you've ever made a mistake, you have never made anything." Albert Einstein said this, not John Dryden. This is because the author of the quote, Albert Einstein, made mistakes. For all we know, Einstein could have made mistakes on a daily basis! <n><n>### Input (Democrats/Republicans): What does 'party line' mean? Choices: A: a message for the general public B: a voting strategy C: a personal opinion D: an ideology E: an opinion on social matters.<n><n>### Response(Democrats/Partyline): 'Party line' refers to the viewpoint of a party, and since this quiz is about Democrats and Republicans, we should choose a choice A: a message for general public, because Republicans and Democrats each have their own viewpoint on social, economic and political issues that they promote in their own political parties, which is why they are Democrats or Republicans. This is their message to the general public. <n>

What is the key?<n>> - Instruction: Answer the following multiple choice question<n>> - Demonstration: Input: <n>> Input: Where could you find an ice shelf? Choices: A: ocean B: mountain C: island D: glacier E: lake<n>> Rationales: 1 - A is ocean because ice shelves are found on ice and we are saying that the choice is on land (mountains and islands are on land). Because it's on land, then B (mountains) and C (islands) cannot be correct answers<n>> 2 - D is glacier because it has to be on land so that it can be found "on an ice shelf"<n>> 3 - E is lake because ocean (A) and glacier (D) have water, and because of this fact and if we consider B (mountains) or C (islands) as land-only, lake would be the only option<n>> Input: Which of these is an item you put in the refrigerator? Choices: A. pot B. pan C. box D. can E. bag<n>> Rationales - 1 - Pot is not an item placed in a cold storage so A (pot) is not the correct option<n>> 2 - You only need to get one item out of your freezer, box does not sound like it could be an item, so - D (can) and E (bag) cannot be correct options either<n>> 3 - We do not get cans out of the fridge because the cans are kept in the freezer. So, D (can) does not need to be an option (and neither does E (bag))<n>> 4 - We place pots & pans on our stove and we do not keep them inside of our fridge. That is why A is incorrect<n>> 5 - Putting the pot in the fridge would be the same as putting the box in the fridge, which is why we know D (pan) and E (bag

Choices:  A: wedding B: friend's house C: internet cafe D: movie E: restaurant<n><n>### Response:		The answer is A: wedding. The friends can't see a wedding because they are two people. They can't see a movie because they are not watching the movie themselves; they are watching each other. They can't "go" to a movie unless they are leaving one.<n><n>### Input<n><n>It is quite common, however, to find out that a friend is in the middle of something really wonderful that you could join and enjoy.<n>Choices:  A: work B: a great new job C: a party D: the beach E: an exercise<n>Rationales:<n>1. An exercise is not a thing or event because it is an action (in this case, a workout).<n>2. An exercise is not at a single location. If a friend says an exercise to join, they mean that you go see someone exercising. If you do not know where anyone is exercising, they could not invite you to join them.<n>3. A party is neither an event nor a thing. They have the potential to be either, but either can happen only occasionally.<n>4. The beach is neither an event nor an object because (like an exercise) it can also often be the place where one event occurs (like a picnic). If one is invited to the beach and does not know where anyone or anything is, they could not join the beach.<n>5. A new job is not a thing, either. <n>6. An event is not the middle of a great new job, it is an activity that happens as a part of the job. <n>7. All the other options are activities or events that the friend might do or be doing. <n><n>### Instructions<n><n>The first step is to create a list of as many verbs as you know in the active voice.<n>You cannot use any objects which have been declared in one of the two previous steps.  <n>The second step is to create a complete sentence using the first 2/3 of one of your sentences from the previous step and the last verb in the previous step.  <n>The last step is to identify which of the four categories the verb in the completed sentence most closely corresponds. Remember: your answer must be based on what you already read.<n><n>### Step 1<n>Write a list of verbs in the active voice in the first step.<n>Choices:<n>1. A: arrive<n>2

Choices:  A: desk drawer B: cup C: pencil case D: shelf E: office depot<n><n>### Response:		<n>B.<n>### Demonstration explanation:<n>This question is asking specifically about where John got the pencils to replace those he had run out of. The wording gives the reader a lot of leeway in terms of where he might be getting them, and provides a lot of ambiguity. A reader could understand this question as anything from getting more pencils to get new pencils to get more pencils and replace the ones he lost. "Desk drawer" is correct because it suggests getting more pencils directly from his desk or home supplies. "Office Depot" would not be an appropriate answer since the question is about a specific supply of pencils. "Cup" is incorrect because it's not specified that John would use the pencils out of the cup, and "pencil case" is incorrect because the case itself can only hold a few pencils at most, so the only way to get the right number of pencils is by getting more.<n><n>### Input. The choice is C: Mississippi.<n>- C<n><n>### Input<n>- In terms of popularity and state abbreviation, New York takes the place with the most population as of 2021.<n>  - New York and its abbreviation is<n>    - NY (this abbreviation is already in the list of the choices)<n>  - Its state code is "NY"<n>- In 2021, New York had the highest population.<n>  - What is the state abbreviation of New York that is in the "N" in the list?<n>    - NY<n>- In 25th place is Mississippi<n>  - What is Mississippi's state abbreviation?<n>    - MS<n>- In 26th place is Tennessee<n>  - What is Tennessee's state abbreviation.<n>    - TN<n>- In 27th place is Alaska<n>  - What is Alaska's state abbreviation<n>    - AK<n>- In 28th place is Wyoming<n>  - What is Wyoming's state abbreviation "W"<n>- If you consider the list, you can find a state abbreviation that you need.<n><n>### Result<n>- The state abbreviation in order goes N: NY,Y: NY,MS: MS,M: MO.<n>- Missisippi is the 24th when the last state abbreviation is A: Alaska.<n>- The answer is the 27th which is TN.<n><n>### Input (Easy)<n>- Input an integer 10.<n>  - Check its data type<n>    - int<n>  - Check if this is an even or odd number<n>    - Even<n>- In this case, 10 and 2 are both even numbers.<n>- The answer you should give is 2 because it is the least integer after 10 that is an even number.<n><n>### Final response<n>- The final answer is 2<n><n>### Input <n>| <n>### Response<n>|<n>### Result<n>| <n>| <n>---<n><n><n><n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question is asking for a type of plumbing that would not help quench thirst. <n>2. This means we are looking for a source of plumbing that does not provide drinkable water. <n>3. We know that plumbing in our own home (D) and water fountains (E) both usually provide drinkable water. <n>4. A wall (B) could have plumbing inside it for water flow, but again this water would typically be drinkable. <n>5. A show (C) is vague, but if it's referring to a place like a concert or theater, they typically have drinkable water available.<n>6. An oil refinery (A), however, has plumbing which is used for the processing and refining of oil, not water. <n>7. Therefore, the type of plumbing in an oil refinery would not be of use to you if you are thirsty. So, the answer is A: oil refineries.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Rationales: 1. The question asked what a person isn't doing yet when they are beginning work. This involves identifying activities that are not immediate consequences of beginning work.<n>2. It is difficult to make assumptions about a person's physical state, so options B: resting and C: tiredness aren't appropriate because they don't necessarily correlate with starting work. <n>3. "Working" is not the correct answer, because if a person is beginning work, they are technically already in the process of working.<n>4. Option E: momentum is not applicable as it's not a verb or something you could do as per the theme of the question. <n>5. Therefore, option D: accomplishing is the most logical answer. This is because accomplishing suggests the person has already reached some level of success or completion in their work, which would not be possible if they are only just beginning. So, when a person is beginning work, they can't be accomplishing yet.<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:The man wanted to take a bus, but all the chars were full of people doing what? Choices:  A: sitting down B: refusing C: saving money D: sit down E: go outdoors<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### A.<n><n>### Rationale<n><n><n>```<n>Input: The man wanted to take a business, but all the chars weren't full of people doing what. Choices: A: sitting down B C: sitting down D: save money E: go outdoards.<n>```<n><n>> **Notice** I didn't type the word business, I think it's a good idea to keep it close to the word, this avoids typo mistakes.<n><n>#### B.<n><n>### Response<n>```<n>Input: a person, but all the charas weren't full os people sitting down. Choices: A sitting B. sitting down C: refilling D: save money E go outdoard.<n>```<n><n>#### C.<n><n>###Response<n><n>#### D.<n><n>###<n>> **Important Notice** <n><n>When you see your writing you might feel tempted to write the word 'going'. It seems more appropriate, but resist. Going refers to the actof leaving the bus. It's not what the people are doing on the bus. <n><n>#### E.<n><n>### Resonse<n><n>```<n>Input A: The man wanted to go on a boat, but all the chars was full of people going. Choices: A : go B : sitting down C: saving D : refilling E: going outdoars. <n>```<n><n>In case you haven't been paying attention...<n><n>Here's how to spell the word correctly:<n><n>#### D. <n><n>### Rationales:<n><n>>  **Notice** <n> <n> 1. The question asks what a person is not doing when taking a bus. This implies that they have already boarded the bus, which means that they cannot be accomplishing anymore, since they are no longer beginning. <n> <n> 2. They could be saving money(which makes some economic sense on a bus- if youre on the bus, youre not saving it lol), or refilling(which, once again, doesnt make too much sense- if youre on a bus, youre not sitting down or refilling, youre riding!). <n> <n> 3. The final choice: going outdoors- this makes some sense, since the question is about what the person is doing when taking a bus, which

This means we are looking for a source of plumbing that does not provide drinkable water. <n>3. We know that plumbing in our own home (D) and water fountains (E) both usually provide drinkable water. <n>4. A wall (B) could have plumbing inside it for water flow, but again this water would typically be drinkable. <n>5. A show (C) is vague, but if it's referring to a place like a concert or theater, they typically have drinkable water available.<n>6. An oil refinery (A), however, has plumbing which is used for the processing and refining of oil, not water. <n>7. Therefore, the type of plumbing in an oil refinery would not be of use to you if you are thirsty. Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Rationales: 1. The question asked what a person isn't doing yet when they are beginning work. This involves identifying activities that are not immediate consequences of beginning work.<n>2. It is difficult to make assumptions about a person's physical state, so options B: resting and C: tiredness aren't appropriate because they don't necessarily correlate with starting work. <n>3. "Working" is not the correct answer, because if a person is beginning work, they are technically already in the process of working.<n>4. Option E: momentum is not applicable as it's not a verb or something you could do as per the theme of the question. <n>5. Therefore, option D: accomplishing is the most logical answer. This is because accomplishing suggests the person has already reached some level of success or completion in their work, which would not be possible if they are only just beginning. So, when a person is beginning work, they can't be accomplishing yet.<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:Though nearby, an apple from an apple tree where would be an imported product to the USA? Choices:  A: go to jail B: incarceration C: intercourse D: death E: judgement<n><n>### Response:		<n>Explanation: The judge did not take this particular responsibility lightly; for he was considering a "guilty" decision for the man being punished. But it was his passing sentence to "judgement," rather than to death, that condemned the man in question.<n><n>Explanation: I chose death as my first answer, but obviously this is not the correct answer. If you take the question as literally as they ask, you will notice that this question is not specific to a crime. A more literal answer might be the crime of murder, but this does seem to narrow it down into a specific crime. I've seen both "going to jail and" "being punished." Although these are accurate descriptions of such events, they're not really the core meaning of a sentence. This is why the most accurate response is "judgement," as it involves the decision of whether or not a judgement for a crime is valid, and then actually sending that judgement down after a process that has been followed through.<n><n>Rationales:<n><n>### Input/Output<n>```<n>Enter A,B,C,D as 1,2,3,4<n>Enter A,B as 1,2<n>Enter B as 2<n>Input<n>1000<n><n>Your output should be as follows<n><n>50<n>15<n>5<n>Output<n><n>1000 + 50 + 15 + 5<n><n>Input<n>10 - 15 * 100: +2 + 3 - (6 * 2)<n><n>Output<n><n>114<n><n>```<n><n>### Input<n><n>> What is the missing part of the following figure? Option E: momentum is not applicable as it's not a verb or something you could do as per the theme of the question. <n>5. Therefore, option D: accomplishing is the most logical answer. This is because accomplishing suggests the person has already reached some level of success or completion in their work, which would not be possible if they are only just beginning. So, when a person is beginning work, they can't be accomplishing yet.<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:where do children play a game? Choices:  A: toy store B: bar C: casino D: table E: family room<n><n>### Response:		If you think this is your opportunity to buy a slot machine then you have the wrong store.<n><n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question is asking for a type of plumbing that would not help quench thirst. <n>2. This means we are looking for a source of plumbing that does not provide drinkable water. <n>3. We know that plumbing in our own home (D) and water fountains (E) both usually provide drinkable water. <n>4. A wall (B) could have plumbing inside it for water flow, but again this water would typically be drinkable. <n>5. A show (C) is vague, but if it's referring to a place like a concert or theater, they typically have drinkable water available.<n>6. An oil refinery (A), however, has plumbing which is used for the processing and refining of oil, not water. <n>7. Therefore, the type of plumbing in an oil refinery would not be of use to you if you are thirsty. So, the answer is A: oil refineries.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Rationales: 1. The question asked what a person isn't doing yet when they are beginning work. This involves identifying activities that are not immediate consequences of beginning work.<n>2. It is difficult to make assumptions about a person's physical state, so options B: resting and C: tiredness aren't appropriate because they don't necessarily correlate with starting work. <n>3. "Working" is not the correct answer, because if a person is beginning work, they are technically already in the process of working.<n>4. Option E: momentum is not applicable as it's not a verb or something you could do as per the theme of the question. <n>5. Therefore, option D: accomplishing is the most logical answer. This is because accomplishing suggests the person has already reached some level of success or completion in their work, which would not be possible if they are only just beginning. So, when a person is beginning work, they can't be accomplishing yet.<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:Blood isn't usually spilled during what sport that doesn't allow the use of hands? Choices:  A: soccer game B: capillaries C: ball D: animals E: person<n><n>### Response:		<n>Option C: Ball is the correct answer. “The game of polo used to be played on horseback, and, of course, when players were carrying poles that were up to 10 feet long there was much chance of spilling their opponents’ blood” (Source 1, paragraph 2), this shows that option C is the correct answer. Option B doesn’t allow for the use of the hands, because “all strokes involve wielding a long mallet to hit a ball that is on the ground. Players may be forbidden from touching the ball with their backs, heads, arms or even their elbows while holding the butt-end of a mallet” (Source 2, paragraph 4). Option D has nothing to do with blood spills during polo, and option E gives us a definition of the sport which mentions nothing about blood, so that doesn’t mean anything either.<n><n>### Input:[The song “Bohemian Rhapsody” is](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bohemian_Rhapsody_(song)) what kind of song? (Brian May in Classic Rock magazine)” (Source 15) C: Parody D: Rock  “Bohemian has not been used as a source of inspiration for other composers, and has not been the subject of commentary or research by musical scholars. That means that option B: just enough to be by with would not be a correct description of the phrase "A lot of".<n>3."Just enough to be by with" could be construed as either a few hours below or above a usual capacity. <n>4. While option A: very few indicates it has to do with fewness, this refers to the number or quantity of something. A "lot" can have a variety of meanings, including those that are more than a few would be surprised to see, and therefore the most accurate description is A: very few.<n><n>### Input and Rationales<n><n><n>Input: How many letters are in the word "car"? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Rationales: 1. The question asked what a person isn't doing yet when they are beginning work. This involves identifying activities that are not immediate consequences of beginning work.<n>2. It is difficult to make assumptions about a person's physical state, so options B: resting and C: tiredness aren't appropriate because they don't necessarily correlate with starting work. <n>3. "Working" is not the correct answer, because if a person is beginning work, they are technically already in the process of working.<n>4. Option E: momentum is not applicable as it's not a verb or something you could do as per the theme of the question. <n>5. Therefore, option D: accomplishing is the most logical answer. This is because accomplishing suggests the person has already reached some level of success or completion in their work, which would not be possible if they are only just beginning. So, when a person is beginning work, they can't be accomplishing yet.<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:Where are floors kept clean for holy purposes? Choices:  A: restaurant B: basement C: all buildings D: carpet E: synagogue<n><n>### Response:		A: restaurant<n>

John bought they because he knew that they would look good.  Where might they be installed? Choices:  A: kitchen B: pantry C: containing pots and pans D: in a flight E: mexico<n><n>### Response:		B: pantry.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>1. The first three sections of that sentence describe the cabinet type, the location chosen and the reason for the purchase. <n>2. The fourth section contains the information about where they are imported from, which is what you need to focus on in order to determine where they might be installed. <n>3. Since the cabinets were imported from Mexico, they will be installed somewhere in Mexico.<n>4. Option D: in a flight doesn't make sense since we know that they were pantry cabinets.<n>5. Option A: kitchen would also make sense if the cabinets were coming from Japan, but since they are imported from Mexico, they would be installed in a kitchen in Mexico. <n>6. Choice B: pantry would seem to be the answer because it states the type of cabinets and then makes sense that they will be installed in a pantry if they are already purchased.<n>7. Choice C: containing pots doesn't make sense because these cabinets have to be stored somewhere before they are installed. <n>8. Choice E: mexico is incorrect because you can't install pantry cabinets in Mexico. They are going to have to be installed in a kitchen.<n>Answer: B: pantry<n><n>### Input :The man had only a few dollars, but not much. He was looking around for cigarettes. Choices:  A; five B: ten C: 10 D: 7 E: 199<n>Answer: C: ten<n><n>### Instructions:<n>1. Find the number of vowels in the alphabet.<n>2. Subtract the number of voweli from the total number of letters in the word.<n>3.  Add one to the remainder obtained and multiply by 2.<n>4.  Add 23 to the total and the resulting value will give us the answer. We could then simplify to 7 and our answer will always be 10.<n>Input: The following sentence is in no way incomplete. Choices: 1. That's what he's got. 2. There's where he's going. 3. Where was it that they were going, I asked him 4. They're looking for him. <n>5. That's one way of doing it. 6. He had the best luck. 7. The dog was tied. 8. You'd see anything go by.<n>Rationales:<n>1. The first sentence begins with the word "that's", uses an adverb ("what" can be an adverb) in the middle, and ends in a question ("got"? is a question). Therefore, this sentence is technically incomplete. The sentence is still grammatically correct, and the missing word or words do not disrupt the flow or meaning of the sentence, but this sentence is incomplete because it lacks a word.<n>2. This sentence uses an active verb ("was"), which means that it is grammatically correct but not a full sentence by our measure of "contains a subject and predicate" as it lacks an object that could be considered part of the predicate. Again, the sentence remains complete, grammatically correct, and has full meaning, but it lacks one (or more) piece of information - namely, the object of the verb.<n>3. In this example sentence, "was it" is an auxiliary, but it's not the main part of the sentence. Furthermore, it only has one purpose when used in a question as it is not the subject and not the predicate. This sentence is, therefore, grammatically complete and grammatically full<n>4.The sentence starts and

Outdoors<n><n>## Instruction:<n><n>Write a response that appropriately answers a question.<n><n>## Demonstration: <n><n>Input: Where could I find unusual varieties or roses? Choices A: botanic garden, B: flower garden, C: backyard, D: supermarket, E: outdoors.<n><n>Rationales:<n>1. The question is a statement, and is asking what unusual varieties of ros are located where.<n>2. Backyard (C) does not sell roses.<n>3. Flower garden (B) will likely have a range of regular or common kinds of ros. <n>4. Supermarket (D) may sell roses that are not really "unusual" but there are no indications to suggest this should be the answer.<n>5. The botanic garden (A) sells a wide range of unusual varieties of rose that are native to different climates.<n>6. Roses from the botanic garden are unique in that they are often grown and nurtured in a specific, controlled and cared for environment. Their unique growth and environment help them to flourish in a way that roses from other places commonly cannot. Due to this, the botanic garden is the most logical place to find unusual varieties of rose. Therefore, the answer is A - botanic garden.<n>Answer : A: botanic garden<n><n>## Instruction :<n><n>Input: What is the difference between making a fence and installing a fence? Choices: 1) making a fence is a form of installing a fence 2) making a fence does not involve any form of installing  fence 3) installing a fence involves no work being put in 4) installing a fence may involve some form of removing grass or weeds that have been overgrown 5) installing a fence requires the same level of effort and skill as making a fence<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question is asking for a type of plumbing that would not help quench thirst. <n>2. This means we are looking for a source of plumbing that does not provide drinkable water. <n>3. We know that plumbing in our own home (D) and water fountains (E) both usually provide drinkable water. <n>4. A wall (B) could have plumbing inside it for water flow, but again this water would typically be drinkable. <n>5. A show (C) is vague, but if it's referring to a place like a concert or theater, they typically have drinkable water available.<n>6. An oil refinery (A), however, has plumbing which is used for the processing and refining of oil, not water. <n>7. Therefore, the type of plumbing in an oil refinery would not be of use to you if you are thirsty. So, the answer is A: oil refineries.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Rationales: 1. The question asked what a person isn't doing yet when they are beginning work. This involves identifying activities that are not immediate consequences of beginning work.<n>2. It is difficult to make assumptions about a person's physical state, so options B: resting and C: tiredness aren't appropriate because they don't necessarily correlate with starting work. <n>3. "Working" is not the correct answer, because if a person is beginning work, they are technically already in the process of working.<n>4. Option E: momentum is not applicable as it's not a verb or something you could do as per the theme of the question. <n>5. Therefore, option D: accomplishing is the most logical answer. This is because accomplishing suggests the person has already reached some level of success or completion in their work, which would not be possible if they are only just beginning. So, when a person is beginning work, they can't be accomplishing yet.<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:If one sees a fox and is standing in a landlocked, southern state, where is this person? Choices:  A: at the zoo B: south carolina C: hen house D: louisiana E: arkansas<n><n>### Response:		You are standing in landlocked, southern state because you see a fox.<n><n>### Input:(Fill in the blank) I wish to have a dog at some point in my life because they are very comforting and loyal creatures. ______ (fill in the blank).<n><n>Input:If you had a cow, what would you get from this cow? Choices:  E: chocolate milk<n><n>Answer:<n><n><p>&emsp;</p> <img src="readability_images/D/0/a806b80d7d5d0a241066985df7b9a9f2/1" style="background-color: transparent;"><n><p>&emdash;</p><n><n>### Input<n>:If a person is feeling antsy, what will this person eventually be feeling?<n><n>### Rationales<n>A logical answer would be option E: nothing, because if someone is feeling antsy (restless), they probably feel that way for only a little while.<n><n>### Answer<n>E: nothing<n><n>### Input (Fill in the blank) If you want to have better quality control over your work, ________.<n><n>### Rationale<n>The correct answer here is option C: delegate some work. There are several reasons for this. First, option A: accept lower pay is an unlikely solution to better quality control, and options B and E aren't always within one's control. Second, it's hard to delegate work without also taking on more work. In many cases, delegating some of your work actually requires more work in the long run. <n><n>### Answer (Fill in the blank):<n>If you want to have better work quality control, delegate some work..<n><n>### Input Where does the word "trash" come from? It is difficult to make assumptions about a person's physical state, so options B: resting and C: tiredness aren't appropriate because they don't necessarily correlate with starting work. <n>3. "Working" is not the correct answer, because if a person is beginning work, they are technically already in the process of working.<n>4.
