People liked her because she was what? Choices:  A: excellent B: fun C: honest D: worthy E: choice<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Input: A: excellent B:fun C:honest D:worthy E:choice<n><n>### Demoration:<n><n>Rationales:<n>1. The question is not asking for specific characteristics of Mary. Rather, it is asking for a common trait of Mary's that makes her relatable to people.<n>2. We know that people like Mary because she is what (E). <n>3. This can mean either: a. People can choose Mary as a friend. <n>b. People perceive Mary to be an attractive person to have as a friend, regardless of what she does. <n>4. We cannot use choice because if Mary is bad, it means she makes bad choices, which would not be someone people generally like to have as friends.<n>5. This brings us to option E: choice. <n>6. We can conclude that Mary was easy to make friends with; people found her easy to choose as someone to be friends with. Thus, Mary was always open about that: people liked her because she was easy to choose friendship with—a person who was always open about that characteristic.<n>Answer: E: choice<n><n>Input: The type of thing that you don't know is, you're missing it.  Choices:  A. an object from the sky B.an event in the world C. the cause of the event D. someone around E. the event<n><n>### Demoration:<n><n>Rationals:<n>1. The first part "The type" makes us want to identify an item to be not included in the description.<n>2. "Missing it" makes us think about someone having an absent object<n>3. So what should be the missing item, the item "above", or the item "event" <n>4. the answer C: "event"<n>5. event occurs in time, but object is a thing<n>6. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question is asking for a type of plumbing that would not help quench thirst. <n>2. This means we are looking for a source of plumbing that does not provide drinkable water. <n>3. We know that plumbing in our own home (D) and water fountains (E) both usually provide drinkable water. <n>4. A wall (B) could have plumbing inside it for water flow, but again this water would typically be drinkable. <n>5. A show (C) is vague, but if it's referring to a place like a concert or theater, they typically have drinkable water available.<n>6. An oil refinery (A), however, has plumbing which is used for the processing and refining of oil, not water. <n>7. Therefore, the type of plumbing in an oil refinery would not be of use to you if you are thirsty. So, the answer is A: oil refineries.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Rationales: 1. The question asked what a person isn't doing yet when they are beginning work. This involves identifying activities that are not immediate consequences of beginning work.<n>2. It is difficult to make assumptions about a person's physical state, so options B: resting and C: tiredness aren't appropriate because they don't necessarily correlate with starting work. <n>3. "Working" is not the correct answer, because if a person is beginning work, they are technically already in the process of working.<n>4. Option E: momentum is not applicable as it's not a verb or something you could do as per the theme of the question. <n>5. Therefore, option D: accomplishing is the most logical answer. This is because accomplishing suggests the person has already reached some level of success or completion in their work, which would not be possible if they are only just beginning. So, when a person is beginning work, they can't be accomplishing yet.<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:The competition was to see who would be the last one the drop the object, the hard part was you had to have your arm extended straight out while what the object? If your language doesn't have a feature to calculate ceil(x,y), you should consider whether you can make the change so you can.<n>Input: The ceiling (floor) of a two-dimensional set of values. Example: 4 2 5 3<n>Output: The ceiling (flooring) of the set; i.e. the smallest number greater than or equal to this input set. Example: 4<n>Rationale: The ceiling is the largest number less than or equal to the set of all coordinates. It's possible to use this principle to calculate the floor, but note that the floor is also the smallest number greater than the set.<n><n>### Difficulties:<n>There may be difficulties in accurately describing and implementing some of the tasks above. This means we are looking for a source of plumbing that does not provide drinkable water. <n>3. We know that plumbing in our own home (D) and water fountains (E) both usually provide drinkable water. <n>4. A wall (B) could have plumbing inside it for water flow, but again this water would typically be drinkable. <n>5. A show (C) is vague, but if it's referring to a place like a concert or theater, they typically have drinkable water available.<n>6. This involves identifying activities that are not immediate consequences of beginning work.<n>2. It is difficult to make assumptions about a person's physical state, so options B: resting and C: tiredness aren't appropriate because they don't necessarily correlate with starting work. <n>3. "Working" is not the correct answer, because if a person is beginning work, they are technically already in the process of working.<n>4. Option E: momentum is not applicable as it's not a verb or something you could do as per the theme of the question. <n>5. Therefore, option D: accomplishing is the most logical answer. This is because accomplishing suggests the person has already reached some level of success or completion in their work, which would not be possible if they are only just beginning. So, when a person is beginning work, they can't be accomplishing yet.<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:What is a convenient place for a bus station? Choices: 	A: whole B: 2% C: skim D: goat <n>Lactose-free milk is a more common type than whole milk, because it is easier to come by and more commonly used, since all humans do in fact have a problem metabolizing it. <n><n>Lactose-deficient or lactose-intolerant individuals would not be able to use whole milk without getting ill, <n><n>But most people would consider whole milk a better option for them to begin with, thus it is not the MOST COMMON choice. <n><n>Answer: A lactose-free dairy beverage is more common than whole cow milk, because it is more easily found and preferred by individuals with a deficiency in the production of the enzyme to process lactose.<n><n>***<n><A name=faq></A><n>**What if I can't write an answer**<n><n><i><p>If the question asks you to identify which things are not x-y, then answer the question, write D for "Not one of the  choices above!" and elaborate. Choices:  A: like more B: nodding C: by wearing rings D: concordance E: shake hands<n><n>### Response:		<n>The question is asking how to let someone know you agree with their statement. <n>1. Option A: Like more is not a sufficient answer as it can be interpreted to mean you want to show more emotion to the statement. <n>2. Option B: Nodding is also not sufficient as it is a general body movement that can be used for many different things. <n>3. Option D: Concordance is not sufficient as it's the term for complete agreement, while the question is asking for a way to show agreement. <n>4. Option E is not correct either as shaking hands is more of a general greeting than a way to show agreement with someone. <n>5. So, the most correct answer is Option C: By wearing rings which is something often done to indicate that you are married. Therefore, people can assume you are married and you agree with this person because of their marriage status, rather than you specifically. <n>Answer: C: by wearing Rings<n><n>### Instructions:Incorrectly filled out forms<n>#### Instructions<n><n>#### Demonstration: <n>

A wall (B) could have plumbing inside it for water flow, but again this water would typically be drinkable. <n>5. An oil refinery (A), however, has plumbing which is used for the processing and refining of oil, not water. <n>7. Therefore, the type of plumbing in an oil refinery would not be of use to you if you are thirsty. So, the answer is A: oil refineries.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Rationales: 1. The question asked what a person isn't doing yet when they are beginning work. This involves identifying activities that are not immediate consequences of beginning work.<n>2. It is difficult to make assumptions about a person's physical state, so options B: resting and C: tiredness aren't appropriate because they don't necessarily correlate with starting work. <n>3. "Working" is not the correct answer, because if a person is beginning work, they are technically already in the process of working.<n>4. Option E: momentum is not applicable as it's not a verb or something you could do as per the theme of the question. <n>5. Therefore, option D: accomplishing is the most logical answer. This is because accomplishing suggests the person has already reached some level of success or completion in their work, which would not be possible if they are only just beginning. So, when a person is beginning work, they can't be accomplishing yet.<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:Along what feature will you find a rosebush? Choices:  A: park B: in the ground C: hedgerow D: temperate climate E: botanical gardens<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Answer: C: hedgerows<n><n>### Explanation:<n>An hedgerow is a line of shrubs and is a feature of a landscape that can be found along the border of a field or path. This answer is not vague or hard to guess because it requires the reader to know the location of the rosebush in order to identify what landscape feature it is next to. <n><n>### Inputs:<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Look at the graph and answer the following multiple choice questions.<n><n>### Examples of plumbing in homes<n><n>### Demystification:<n><n>### Input#1:For what do houses have plumbing? This is incorrect because 'B' mentions the opposite, as it includes 'though'.<n>4. 'C' mentions 'happiness', but that has nothing to do with the eye, nor does it make any sense to suffer eye what, when the only thing happening to the eye is the straining to read, nothing is being 'done' to the eye that would make the man happy. <n>5. In each part of this question there is a noun (someone, a person, a group of people, etc.) and a verb (calm, do, what are you doing, are you doing, are they doing). The person answering the question must provide a noun and a verb. In this case, however, answer choices B is a noun while answer choice A is a verb. Therefore, answer choice A is correct.<n>Answers:Because all three answer choices are nouns, the right one is "C" which is reading books.<n><n>Input：You are eating in an excellent restaurant. Choices:  A: lie down B: run away C: bite D: keep alive E: feel pain<n><n>### Response:		I have to agree with you about your response for this one. The question is simply whether the wild animals will feel pain or not. As per your answer choice, wild animals will feel pain.<n><n>Rationales:1. The reason for this is that wild animals, by nature, are not humans. Thus, this is a violation of the law of nature of animals, given that animals do not feel pain.<n>2. Option A: lie down is not appropriate for this question because animals have no means of speech and thus could not tell us that they feel pain.<n>3. Option B: run away does not apply because unless the animals already have means to speak to us, they cannot tell us that they feel the pain, and thus, will not run away.<n>4. Option D: keep alive is not possible, as we are violating the natural order of animals to ask them to feel pain in the first place.<n>5. Option E: feel pain makes the most sense here. This is because wild animals are not human, and thus, cannot lie down or run away. As such, their choices for their natural reaction to touching people is either to hide or feel pain. <n>Because of this reason, option E: feel pain is the correct answer.<n><n>Answer: E: feel pain<n>

Choices:  A: zoo B: workplace C: sky D: new york city E: many places<n><n>### Response:		E: Many Places.<n><n>## Solution<n>Elevator Pitch<n>An elevator pitch is a brief and succinct summary of what a project is all about, including your vision or vision for the project, and how this project will aid your career, education, etc. This elevator pitch should be no more than ten or fifteen sentences, however, and it should be concise and easy to read without using complex or lengthy jargon.<n><n>## Output: Elevator pitch:<n>I am a [title] who has created this project in order to solve these following problems using these specific technologies. I believe my project will be valuable for these reasons. <n><n>## Input<n>Ask a follow-up question, or rephrase the original question in a different way.<n><n>## Input<n>Input: How do we know when we have won? Choices: A: we lose B: the team has lost, we win C: we lose D: the team has won, we lose E: neither team has gotten what they wanted<n><n>## Output: Answer: We know that we have lost when our team has lost, and we know that we have won when our team wins.<n><n>## Background<n>In computer science, it is sometimes necessary to output the value of a variable, even after a variable has been assigned a value. Using the assignment operator ( = ), we can assign a variable a value, and to use the output operator, the values of the following output operator (print()) will be printed to the screen.<n><n>## Output<n>Output an integer, floating-point number, or boolean value.<n><n>## Context<n>The output of the value to a user without any context is very impractical, as it does not give users the necessary information to decide how to proceed. <n>For example, just telling a user that the value of "x" is "5" won't help because the user doesn't know what this means, and whether it is good or bad. <n>Therefore, an output must accompany any variable, and sometimes outputting a variable's value is necessary in order for a program to execute correctly. <n><n>## Output<n>The following are examples of output statements, or assignment statements:<n>```<n>output("Hello ")<n>output("World!")<n>```<n>These would print the statement "Hello world" to the terminal.

John preferred glass, and wished he was somewhere else.  Where does he want to be? Choices:  A: cupboard B: anywhere else C: everything D: own home E: garbage dump<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>Answer: A<n><n>### Rationale:<n>Glass and plastic are both used to make jars. Jars are also the containers used to hold items in the kitchen. <n><n>Plastic is used to make most of the objects in the kitchen, except for glass. Anything that is glass is not plastic. John liked glass over plastic. John is being held against his will and does not want to be in the kitchen. In this scenario, we know glass is not plastic in the kitchen and the person doesn't want to be in the room. There are other rooms in the house, and we can't assume how he would feel about those rooms.<n><n>Answer: D<n><n><n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question is asking for a type of plumbing that would not help quench thirst. <n>2. This means we are looking for a source of plumbing that does not provide drinkable water. <n>3. We know that plumbing in our own home (D) and water fountains (E) both usually provide drinkable water. <n>4. A wall (B) could have plumbing inside it for water flow, but again this water would typically be drinkable. <n>5. A show (C) is vague, but if it's referring to a place like a concert or theater, they typically have drinkable water available.<n>6. An oil refinery (A), however, has plumbing which is used for the processing and refining of oil, not water. <n>7. Therefore, the type of plumbing in an oil refinery would not be of use to you if you are thirsty. So, the answer is A: oil refineries.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Rationales: 1. The question asked what a person isn't doing yet when they are beginning work. This involves identifying activities that are not immediate consequences of beginning work.<n>2. It is difficult to make assumptions about a person's physical state, so options B: resting and C: tiredness aren't appropriate because they don't necessarily correlate with starting work. <n>3. "Working" is not the correct answer, because if a person is beginning work, they are technically already in the process of working.<n>4. Option E: momentum is not applicable as it's not a verb or something you could do as per the theme of the question. <n>5. Therefore, option D: accomplishing is the most logical answer. This is because accomplishing suggests the person has already reached some level of success or completion in their work, which would not be possible if they are only just beginning. So, when a person is beginning work, they can't be accomplishing yet.<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:Where do you buy a glass of wine? Choices:  A: art show B: basement C: bar D: church E: basement<n><n>### Response:		(The response is in italics.)<n>Rationales: The question indicates that the purchaser of wine is looking for a place to buy a glass of wine (hinted by the inclusion of the phrase "glass of wine"). <n><n>Input: An author may be a famous man, a famous woman, or a famous woman who is a mathematician. Choices:  A. famous man B. famous woman C. famous man who is a famous woman D. famous woman who is a famous mathematician<n>Rationale: 1. The "who is" implies that the author is not the famous man or woman themself (hinted by use of pronouns "him" and "her"), but another famous person, "the man" and "the woman". Therefore, the author could be any of the options. <n><n>2. Option A: F: famous man only refers to an author being a man, not both a famous man and a famous woman.<n>3. Option B: F: famous woman only refers to an author who is a woman.<n>4. Option C refers to "the man" and not "the author" so we know the author can be neither of the choices.<n>5. Option D is the best answer option as it refers to "the woman" and "the famous mathematician". <n>6. "Famous mathematician" indicates "famous" is used as an adjective, therefore, "the famous woman is" can refer to "the woman" specifically, not a group containing the woman.<n><n>Input: Every time you see one of the world's great cities. Choices: D. A place to visit as a tourist B. It is a wonderful place to have a business meeting. C. A place where you would likely become acquainted with a beautiful woman<n><n>Rationales:<n>1. The prompt indicates that this is information that can be gained when "seeing one of the world' s greatest cities". It implies that every time one sees some of the world's greatest cities, they would know whether or not it's a tourist destination (B), a business meeting location (C), or somewhere to meet a beautiful woman (D). <n><n>2. All possibilities B: A place to visit as tourist and C: A place where you would like to become acquainted with a beutiful woman are out as they involve seeing a
